businessSummary.oneLiner: Government and enterprise AI data analytics platform , transforming from core US defense/intel partner to commercial AI powerhouse
businessSummary.description: Palantir builds software platforms that analyze and integrate complex data. Since the AIP (AI Platform) launch, the commercial segment has grown explosively. Q4 2025 revenue hit $1.407B (+70% YoY), with US commercial revenue surging to $507M (+137% YoY). Full-year 2026 guidance stands at $7.18-7.20B (+61% YoY), well above prior consensus. PLTR opened at $133.85 on March 1 as technical weakness and broader AI software sector headwinds persist, though the contract pipeline remains strong with the DHS $1B BPA and fresh DISA authorization.
howTheyMakeMoney: US Government: DoD, CIA, NSA, DHS data analytics , Q4 $570M (+66% YoY)
US Commercial: Enterprise AI/data analytics , Q4 $507M (+137% YoY), fastest-growing segment
International Government: NATO allies and other foreign government contracts
International Commercial: Global enterprise customers (Airbus Skywise, etc.)
Subscription SaaS model: Annual contracts, top 20 customers avg $94M/yr (+45% YoY)
keyProducts: AIP (Artificial Intelligence Platform) , Enterprise AI integration, core growth engine
Gotham , Government/defense data analysis and decision-making platform
Foundry , Enterprise data integration and operations platform
Apollo , Software deployment automation and management
TITAN , US Army next-gen intelligence system

keyMetrics.name: P/E (TTM)
keyMetrics.interpretation: High valuation at EPS $0.63. Reflects hyper-growth premium

keyMetrics.name: Forward P/E
keyMetrics.interpretation: FY2026 EPS $1.32 expected. Still priced for perfection

keyMetrics.name: Operating Margin
keyMetrics.interpretation: High for SaaS. Economies of scale taking effect

keyMetrics.name: PEG
keyMetrics.interpretation: Premium to growth, but reflects AI leader positioning

growthDrivers.title: US Commercial +115% Guidance , AIP Adoption Accelerating
growthDrivers.description: Motley Fool analysis: 115% US commercial growth guidance proves AIP adoption is compounding. Full-year 2026 revenue guidance of $7.18-7.20B (+61% YoY) significantly exceeds prior Street consensus.

growthDrivers.title: DHS $1B 5-Year BPA + DISA IL5/IL6 Authorization
growthDrivers.description: Signed $1B 5-year blanket purchase agreement with DHS (2/19), covering CBP, ICE, Secret Service, FEMA, TSA, and CISA without competitive bidding. DISA authorized Palantir Federal Cloud Service Forward for IL5/IL6 edge deployments, shortening the pilot-to-production runway for defense customers.

growthDrivers.title: Rackspace Partnership + UK's Largest Defense Contract
growthDrivers.description: New collaboration with Rackspace Technology to deploy Foundry and AIP in highly regulated industries. Secured UK's largest-ever defense contract and a $7.6M Australian Department of Defence deal, expanding the international government pipeline.

growthDrivers.title: Citi Strong Buy $260, Daiwa Buy $180 , Institutional Conviction Holds
growthDrivers.description: Citi maintains Strong Buy at $260, Daiwa upgraded to Buy ($180, Feb 10), UBS Buy ($180), Rosenblatt Buy ($150). Consensus target of $188-189 implies 41% upside. Top analysts view the YTD selloff as a buying opportunity.

competitiveAdvantage.summary: Undisputed #1 in government/defense AI, rapidly building commercial AI position through AIP. Irreplaceable in data security + AI integration.

moats.description: Highest-level clearances with CIA, NSA, DHS. DHS BPA enables no-bid procurement across six agencies. DISA IL5/IL6 authorization extends edge deployment reach.
More customers drive better AI models, which attract more customers. Virtuous cycle compounds over time.
Deeply integrated into customer data infrastructure. DHS 5-year BPA and multi-year Airbus Skywise renewal prove stickiness.

competitors.name: Snowflake
competitors.detail: Expanding AI in data cloud but notably weak in the government sector.

competitors.name: Databricks
competitors.detail: Private, data lakehouse architecture. Competes in enterprise AI.

competitors.name: C3.ai
competitors.detail: Enterprise AI platform. Significantly behind in growth and scale.

competitors.name: Google (Alphabet)
competitors.detail: DoD tapped Google Gemini for GenAI.mil platform. Signals government AI budget is spreading across multiple vendors.

recentNews.significance: DoD selected Google Gemini as the backbone of the GenAI.mil platform. Raises questions about government AI budget concentration versus Palantir's differentiated security clearance advantages.

analystOpinions.notableComment: Citi Strong Buy ($260), Daiwa Buy ($180, upgraded Feb 10), UBS Buy ($180), Rosenblatt Buy ($150). Consensus target $188-189 (+41% upside). TipRanks: 'Selloff is a buying opportunity.'

risks.title: Technical Breakdown , RSI 37-38, Below All Key SMAs
risks.description: Price below the 5-day SMA ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), and 50-day ($165.19). MACD bearish. RSI 37-38 approaching oversold but no confirmed reversal signal yet.

risks.title: YTD -24% , Dual Headwinds: Macro Rotation and Valuation Reset
risks.description: Broad AI software selloff driven by sector rotation and valuation skepticism. P/E ~213x remains exposed to any growth disappointment or rate sensitivity.

risks.title: Google Gemini Enters DoD , Government AI Budget Diversification
risks.description: The Pentagon's GenAI.mil platform selected Google Gemini as its core. While Palantir's classification-level clearances are distinct, the deal signals government AI spending may be spread across multiple vendors.

risks.title: ICE Controversy + DOGE Budget Cut Risk
risks.description: Palantir tools linked to ICE tip-collection operations, creating ESG and reputational overhang. DOGE-driven federal budget reductions could weigh on government contract renewals.

risks.title: Persistent Insider Selling + SBC Dilution
risks.description: Executive auto-sell programs continue. Stock-based compensation dilution running at +4.67% YoY.

buyReasons.title: Consensus Target $188-189, +41% Upside from Current Levels
buyReasons.rationale: Citi $260, UBS $180, Daiwa $180. 14 institutional Buy ratings. TipRanks analysts call the selloff a buying opportunity.

buyReasons.title: DHS $1B BPA + DISA IL5/IL6 Authorization , Government Pipeline Intact
buyReasons.rationale: No-bid procurement structure locks in DHS revenue across six agencies. DISA approval shortens the defense pilot-to-production cycle.

buyReasons.title: Q4 Revenue +70%, 2026 Guidance $7.18-7.20B , Top-Tier Fundamentals
buyReasons.rationale: US commercial +137%, government +66%. Full-year 2026 guidance of +61% significantly beats prior Street estimates. AIP adoption momentum is real.

buyReasons.title: RSI 37-38 Near Oversold , 35% Below 52-Week High
buyReasons.rationale: At $133.85, PLTR is 35% below the 52-week high of $207.52. Historically, oversold RSI levels in quality AI names have preceded meaningful bounces. Attractive entry for long-term investors on a dollar-cost averaging basis.

overallOpinion: Palantir opened March 1 at $133.85, extending a bruising year-to-date decline of roughly 24% as AI software valuations face a broad market reassessment. The Pentagon's decision to tap Google Gemini as the backbone of its new GenAI.mil platform added to the anxiety, raising questions about whether government AI budgets will increasingly be spread across multiple vendors rather than concentrated in Palantir's platforms.

The fundamental picture, however, tells a different story. The DHS $1 billion five-year blanket purchase agreement, fresh DISA authorization for IL5/IL6 edge deployments, the UK's largest-ever Palantir defense contract, and a new Rackspace partnership for regulated industries all arrived in recent weeks. Q4 revenue grew 70% year over year to $1.407 billion, and 2026 guidance of $7.18-7.20 billion (+61%) significantly exceeded Street expectations. Citi maintains a Strong Buy at $260, and the analyst consensus target sits at $188-189, implying 41% upside from current levels. TipRanks views the selloff as an opportunity.

The technical picture is the clearest bear case: PLTR is trading below its 5-day ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), and 50-day ($165.19) moving averages, with a bearish MACD and an RSI of 37-38 that is approaching oversold territory but has yet to produce a confirmed reversal signal. At 35% below the 52-week high of $207.52 and still priced at roughly 213x trailing earnings, the stock sits in a precarious middle ground , strong underlying business, deteriorating near-term technicals, and a valuation that leaves little margin for error. For long-term investors, the current zone may represent a phased accumulation opportunity; for short-term traders, the path of least resistance remains downward until technical momentum turns.

x.hook: PLTR down 24% YTD: inflection or further pain?
x.text:
PLTR opened March 1 at $133.85. Down 24% YTD.

- DoD picked Google Gemini as the core of GenAI.mil, raising government AI budget diversification risk
- DHS $1B 5-year BPA (2/19): CBP, ICE, TSA and 3 more agencies on no-bid procurement
- DISA IL5/IL6 edge authorization, UK's largest-ever defense contract, Rackspace partnership
- Q4 revenue $1.407B (+70% YoY), US commercial $507M (+137%). 2026 guidance $7.18-7.20B (+61%)
- P/E 213x, PEG 2.30. Below 5-day ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), 50-day ($165.19) SMAs
- RSI 37-38 near oversold, MACD bearish. No confirmed reversal signal yet
- Consensus $188 (+41%). Citi $260, UBS $180. 35% below 52-week high of $207.52

threads.hook: PLTR -24% YTD: buying opportunity or more downside?
threads.text:
Palantir opened March 1 at $133.85, extending a 24% year-to-date decline.

The biggest new variable today: the Pentagon selected Google Gemini as the backbone of its GenAI.mil platform. That raises real questions about whether government AI budgets will spread across multiple vendors instead of concentrating in Palantir. Palantir argues its classification-level clearances are a different category entirely, but the market is clearly unnerved.

The contract pipeline tells a different story. The DHS $1 billion five-year blanket purchase agreement (signed 2/19) covers CBP, ICE, Secret Service, FEMA, TSA, and CISA, all without competitive bidding. DISA authorized Palantir Federal Cloud Service Forward for IL5/IL6 edge deployments, shortening the pilot-to-production runway for defense customers. Add the UK's largest-ever Palantir defense contract, an Australian DoD deal worth $7.6M, and a new Rackspace partnership for regulated industries.

Fundamentals remain top-tier. Q4 revenue hit $1.407B (+70% YoY), with US commercial surging to $507M (+137% YoY). The 2026 guidance of $7.18-7.20B (+61%) significantly beat prior Street estimates, confirming AIP adoption is compounding.

Technicals are the clearest bear case. PLTR is trading below its 5-day SMA ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), and 50-day ($165.19). RSI sits at 37-38, approaching oversold but without a confirmed reversal. MACD is bearish. At P/E 213x and PEG 2.30, there is little margin for error.

Analyst consensus target is $188 (+41% upside). Citi holds Strong Buy at $260, UBS and Daiwa at $180. At 35% below the 52-week high of $207.52, the case for phased accumulation builds, but the path of least resistance remains down until technical momentum turns.

35% below 52-week high of $207.52. Phased accumulation zone for long-term investors.

witty.text:
Palantir's 2026 scorecard.

Contracts column: DHS $1B BPA, UK's largest defense deal ever, DISA IL5/IL6 edge auth, Rackspace partnership. Q4 revenue $1.407B, up 70%. US commercial +137%.

Stock price column: down 24% YTD, RSI 37, trading below the 5-day ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), and 50-day ($165.19).

New plot twist: Google Gemini just moved into the DoD's GenAI.mil. The market's take: 'Great. Now explain P/E 213x without a monopoly.'

Consensus says $188 (+41%). Citi says $260. The chart says something else entirely. One of them will be right.

empathy.hook: Holding PLTR down 24%? This is for you.
empathy.text:
If you are holding Palantir through a 24% year-to-date drop, that is genuinely rough.

Today added a new layer of anxiety: Google Gemini became the backbone of the Pentagon's GenAI.mil platform. The implication that government AI budgets might fragment is unsettling, even if Palantir's classification-level clearances are in a different league.

The company itself keeps delivering. DHS $1B five-year BPA across six agencies on no-bid procurement. DISA IL5/IL6 edge authorization. UK's largest-ever defense contract. Q4 revenue $1.407B, up 70%. US commercial $507M, up 137%. 2026 guidance $7.18-7.20B, up 61%.

RSI is at 37-38, approaching oversold. The 5-day ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), and 50-day ($165.19) are all overhead. P/E 213x, PEG 2.30. Consensus is $188, which is 41% above where PLTR trades now. Citi sees $260. At 35% below the 52-week high of $207.52, the math for phased buying is starting to make sense.

fact.text:
Palantir opened March 1 at $133.85, extending a 24% year-to-date decline.

The biggest new variable today: the Pentagon selected Google Gemini as the backbone of its GenAI.mil platform. That raises real questions about whether government AI budgets will spread across multiple vendors instead of concentrating in Palantir. Palantir argues its classification-level clearances are a different category entirely, but the market is clearly unnerved.

The contract pipeline tells a different story. The DHS $1 billion five-year blanket purchase agreement (signed 2/19) covers CBP, ICE, Secret Service, FEMA, TSA, and CISA, all without competitive bidding. DISA authorized Palantir Federal Cloud Service Forward for IL5/IL6 edge deployments, shortening the pilot-to-production runway for defense customers. Add the UK's largest-ever Palantir defense contract, an Australian DoD deal worth $7.6M, and a new Rackspace partnership for regulated industries.

witty.hook: PLTR: best contract quarter, worst price action
witty.text:
Palantir's Q1 2026 press releases read like a highlight reel: DHS $1B five-year BPA, DISA IL5/IL6 edge authorization, UK's largest defense contract ever, Australian DoD deal, Rackspace partnership for regulated industries. Q4 revenue was $1.407B, up 70%. US commercial up 137%.

The stock is down 24% year-to-date.

The plot twist that broke the chart today: Google Gemini landed inside the Pentagon's GenAI.mil platform. The market immediately asked the question Palantir holders have been dreading: if the DoD uses Gemini for its AI platform, is Palantir's government moat narrower than the P/E of 213x implies?

Citi thinks the answer to that is $260. Consensus says $188, which is 41% above today's price. RSI is at 37. The 52-week high is $207.52, which is 35% away. PEG is 2.30.

Something has to give. The only question is what moves first.

empathy.hook: Holding Palantir through -24%? Here is the full picture.
empathy.text:
Being down 24% on a position in two months is not easy. If you are holding Palantir right now, here is an honest look at what is happening.

What is working against you: The entire AI software sector is being repriced. Today, Google Gemini was selected as the backbone of the DoD's GenAI.mil platform, which rattled confidence in Palantir's perceived government moat. RSI is at 37-38, below the 5-day SMA ($133.79), 20-day ($142.38), and 50-day ($165.19), with a bearish MACD. At P/E 213x and PEG 2.30, technicians are right to flag the risk. Stockinvest.us has it on a strong sell.

What is working for you: Q4 revenue came in at $1.407B, up 70% year over year. US commercial hit $507M, up 137%. The 2026 guidance of $7.18-7.20B, up 61%, blew past Street expectations. The DHS $1B five-year BPA locks in no-bid procurement across six agencies. DISA's IL5/IL6 edge authorization shortens the defense sales cycle. The UK contract was Palantir's largest ever there. AIP adoption is accelerating, not stalling.

Citi's target is $260. The street consensus is $188, which is 41% above where PLTR is today. At 35% below the 52-week high of $207.52, the case for dollar-cost averaging is not unreasonable if you believe the business fundamentals over the near-term chart.
